categories.name: SaaS
categories.description: Software-as-a-service ideas you can build and launch this weekend. Recurring revenue, scalable, and perfect for solo founders.

faqs.question: What is a SaaS startup?
faqs.answer: SaaS (Software as a Service) is a software distribution model where applications are hosted in the cloud and provided to customers over the internet on a subscription basis. Instead of buying and installing software, users pay a monthly or annual fee for access.

faqs.question: How much can a micro-SaaS make?
faqs.answer: Micro-SaaS products typically target $1K-$10K monthly recurring revenue (MRR). Many solo founders achieve $5K-$20K/month with focused niche products. The key is solving a specific problem extremely well.

faqs.question: What tech stack is best for SaaS in 2026?
faqs.answer: Popular stacks include Next.js + Supabase for rapid development, or traditional choices like Rails or Django. The best stack is one you can ship quickly with. AI coding tools like Cursor have made full-stack development accessible to more founders.

faqs.question: How long does it take to build a SaaS MVP?
faqs.answer: With modern tools and AI assistance, a focused MVP can be built in a weekend (8-16 hours). The key is scoping aggressively—launch with one core feature that delivers clear value, then iterate based on user feedback.

categories.name: Productivity
categories.description: Tools that help people work smarter, not harder. From meeting management to task automation, these ideas save users time.

faqs.question: What makes a productivity app successful?
faqs.answer: The best productivity apps do one thing exceptionally well. They integrate into existing workflows rather than requiring users to change habits. Focus on reducing friction and saving measurable time.

faqs.question: How do productivity apps make money?
faqs.answer: Common models include freemium (free basic tier, paid pro features), subscription pricing ($5-$20/month for individuals, $10-$50/seat for teams), and one-time purchases for simpler tools.

categories.name: Health & Wellness
categories.description: Digital health and wellness solutions. From fitness apps to nutrition planners, help people live healthier lives.

faqs.question: Do health apps need FDA approval?
faqs.answer: Most wellness and fitness apps don't require FDA approval. However, if your app diagnoses, treats, or prevents disease, or connects to medical devices, you may need regulatory clearance. When in doubt, consult a healthcare regulatory attorney.

faqs.question: What's the best niche in health tech?
faqs.answer: Underserved niches with passionate users include mental health for specific demographics, nutrition for specialized diets, fitness for niche sports, and chronic condition management tools.

categories.name: Marketplace
categories.description: Two-sided marketplace ideas connecting buyers and sellers. Higher complexity but massive potential with network effects.

faqs.question: How do you solve the chicken-and-egg problem?
faqs.answer: Start with supply—recruit providers first with a compelling value proposition. Use manual effort ('do things that don't scale') to match early supply with demand. Many successful marketplaces started by focusing on a single geography or niche.

faqs.question: What's the typical take rate for marketplaces?
faqs.answer: Take rates vary by industry: 5-15% for services, 15-30% for digital products, and up to 30-50% for high-touch services. Lower take rates work when transaction volumes are high.

categories.name: AI Tools
categories.description: Leverage AI APIs to build powerful tools. The AI wrapper opportunity is real—add UI, workflow, and domain expertise on top of foundation models.

faqs.question: Are AI wrappers a viable business?
faqs.answer: Yes, when you add genuine value beyond raw API access. Successful AI wrappers offer better UX, domain-specific prompts, workflow integration, and cost optimization. The key is solving a specific problem, not just providing generic AI access.

faqs.question: Which AI API should I use?
faqs.answer: OpenAI (GPT-4) and Anthropic (Claude) are leaders for text. For specific tasks, consider specialized models. Start with one provider, and add fallbacks later. Cost matters—Claude and GPT-4 are similar in capability but pricing varies by use case.

categories.name: Automation
categories.description: Tools that automate repetitive tasks. From invoice reminders to data entry, save businesses hours every week.

faqs.question: What tasks are best to automate?
faqs.answer: Look for tasks that are: repetitive (done frequently), rule-based (clear logic), time-consuming, and error-prone when done manually. Common examples include data entry, report generation, follow-ups, and status updates.

faqs.question: Build vs integrate with Zapier/Make?
faqs.answer: Start with existing automation platforms to validate demand. Build custom when: you need better UX, higher reliability, lower per-action costs, or features the platforms don't support. Many successful automation businesses started as Zapier alternatives for specific niches.

categories.name: Education
categories.description: Educational technology ideas. From course platforms to learning tools, help people acquire new skills.

faqs.question: Is the online education market saturated?
faqs.answer: The generic market is crowded, but niches are underserved. Focus on specific skills, industries, or learning styles. Cohort-based courses, community-driven learning, and AI-personalized education are growing areas.

faqs.question: How do edtech products monetize?
faqs.answer: Common models include course sales (one-time or subscription), certification fees, enterprise licensing, and freemium with premium content. B2B (selling to employers) often has higher price points than B2C.

categories.name: B2B
categories.description: Business-to-business software ideas. Higher price points, longer sales cycles, but more predictable revenue.

faqs.question: How is B2B different from B2C?
faqs.answer: B2B typically has: higher price points ($50-$500+/month vs $5-$20), longer sales cycles, multiple stakeholders in decisions, need for security/compliance features, and focus on ROI over consumer delight.

faqs.question: Can solo founders build B2B products?
faqs.answer: Yes. Many successful B2B products started as solo projects. Focus on SMB (small-medium business) initially—they have simpler buying processes than enterprises. Expand upmarket as you grow.

categories.name: Developer Tools
categories.description: Tools for developers, by developers. APIs, CLIs, and platforms that make coding faster and easier.

faqs.question: How do developer tools acquire users?
faqs.answer: Developers discover tools through: technical content (blogs, tutorials), GitHub presence, Hacker News/Reddit, word of mouth, and integrations with popular tools. Build in public and share your learnings.

faqs.question: What's the best pricing model for dev tools?
faqs.answer: Freemium with generous free tiers works well—developers try before buying. Usage-based pricing aligns with value delivered. Per-seat pricing works for team tools. Avoid gating basic functionality too aggressively.

categories.name: E-commerce
categories.description: Tools and platforms for online sellers. From inventory management to marketing automation.

faqs.question: What e-commerce niches are underserved?
faqs.answer: Look for niches with: passionate buyers (hobbies, collectibles), high AOV (luxury, B2B supplies), or underserved demographics. Also consider tools for sellers—there are always pain points in the e-commerce stack.

categories.name: Creator Tools
categories.description: Tools for content creators, influencers, and digital entrepreneurs. Help creators monetize and manage their businesses.

faqs.question: What do creators need most?
faqs.answer: Creators struggle with: monetization beyond ads, audience management, content repurposing, sponsorship management, and business operations (invoicing, contracts). Tools that save time or increase revenue win.

categories.name: Fintech
categories.description: Financial technology ideas. From payment processing to personal finance, help people manage money better.

faqs.question: Is fintech heavily regulated?
faqs.answer: Yes, but not all fintech is equally regulated. Tools that help with budgeting or financial education have minimal regulation. Anything touching payments, lending, or investments requires compliance. Consider starting with less regulated adjacent problems.

tools.name: Cursor
tools.description: Build full-stack applications with AI pair programming. Cursor understands your codebase and helps you write, refactor, and debug code faster.
gettingStarted: Open your project folder or create a new one
Press Cmd+K (Mac) or Ctrl+K (Windows) to start AI chat
Describe what you want to build in natural language
Use Cmd+L to chat about your entire codebase

tools.name: Claude
tools.description: Claude excels at understanding complex requirements, writing clean code, and explaining technical concepts. Great for planning, debugging, and code review.
gettingStarted: Go to claude.ai and create an account
Start a new conversation with your project idea
Ask Claude to help plan your architecture
Use Claude to generate code snippets
Copy code to your IDE and iterate

tools.name: Bolt.new
tools.description: Build and deploy full-stack web applications directly in your browser. Great for rapid prototyping and simple applications.
gettingStarted: Go to bolt.new in your browser

tools.name: v0 by Vercel
tools.description: Generate React components and UI designs from text descriptions. Perfect for quickly building beautiful interfaces.
gettingStarted: Describe the UI component you need

tools.name: Lovable
tools.description: Build full applications with natural language. Lovable handles the entire stack and deploys your app automatically.

tools.name: Replit
tools.description: Code, create, and learn together with a powerful, simple, and collaborative IDE, compiler, and interpreter.
gettingStarted: Start a new Repl in your language

tools.name: Windsurf
tools.description: The first agentic IDE. Windsurf combines AI assistance with deep codebase understanding for faster development.

tools.name: No-Code Tools
tools.description: A collection of no-code tools including Bubble, Webflow, Softr, and Glide that let you build apps without writing code.
gettingStarted: Choose a no-code platform (Bubble, Webflow, Softr)
Start with a template if available

revenueGoals.name: $1K/Month
revenueGoals.description: Achievable with a small customer base. Perfect for validating demand and building your first profitable product.
revenueGoals.methodology: At $1K/month, you need: 100 customers at $10/month, 50 customers at $20/month, or 20 customers at $50/month. The key is finding a niche where you can reach and convert 20-100 paying customers.

revenueGoals.name: $5K/Month
revenueGoals.description: Enough to replace most salaries or build significant side income. Requires a more established customer base.
revenueGoals.methodology: At $5K/month, you need: 250 customers at $20/month, 100 customers at $50/month, or 50 customers at $100/month. Focus on higher-value customers or add premium tiers.

revenueGoals.name: $10K/Month
revenueGoals.description: A full business that can support a founder and potentially a small team. Significant but achievable.
revenueGoals.methodology: At $10K/month, you need: 200 customers at $50/month, 100 customers at $100/month, or 20 enterprise customers at $500/month. Consider moving upmarket or adding annual plans.

revenueGoals.name: Passive Income
revenueGoals.description: Products that generate revenue with minimal ongoing effort. Set it up once and let it run.
revenueGoals.methodology: Truly passive products are rare, but low-maintenance is achievable. Look for: one-time purchases, subscription products with low churn, and automated delivery.

revenueGoals.name: Quick Wins
revenueGoals.description: Ideas with short time-to-revenue. Get your first paying customer within weeks, not months.

keywords.primary: mvp ideas that make money fast

revenueGoals.methodology: Quick wins come from: solving urgent problems, targeting buyers with budget authority, and having a clear value proposition. Pre-sell before building when possible.
